name: Luanda
fun_fact: Fun fact: Luanda was once the world's most expensive city for expatriates - a simple pizza could cost $50 and a 2-bedroom apartment $15,000/month during the oil boom! Today it's more affordable but remains Angola's vibrant, music-filled capital.

hero_dishes.name: Muamba de Galinha
hero_dishes.description: Chicken stewed in palm oil with okra, garlic, and chili - Angola's national dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Muamba sauce is the heart of Angolan cuisine - the word means 'sauce' in Kimbundu. Palm oil gives it the distinctive orange color
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurante Cozinha de AvÃ³, Pimms, traditional Angolan restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Calulu
hero_dishes.description: Fish or meat stewed with dried fish, okra, tomatoes, and sweet potato leaves
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional dish showing Portuguese and African fusion - the dried fish adds intense umami
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local restaurants in Ilha do Cabo, Mercado do Kinaxixi area

hero_dishes.name: Mufete
hero_dishes.description: Grilled fish (often tilapia) served with farofa (cassava flour), beans, and palm oil sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: A coastal favorite - the fish is often grilled over charcoal on the beach
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Beachfront restaurants on Ilha de Luanda, Cais de Quatro

hero_dishes.name: Funge
hero_dishes.description: Smooth cassava flour porridge, the essential accompaniment to all stews
hero_dishes.origin_story: Like fufu or ugali in other African countries - eaten by rolling pieces and scooping stew
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served with virtually every traditional meal across Luanda

signature_drinks.name: Cuca Beer
signature_drinks.description: Angola's most popular beer, light lager perfect for the tropical climate
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Ice cold at bars and beach clubs, often with grilled seafood

signature_drinks.name: Kissangua
signature_drinks.description: Traditional fermented drink made from corn flour and sugar
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At celebrations and markets - mildly alcoholic and slightly sour

food_culture_notes: Portuguese colonial influence strong - bacalhau (salt cod) still popular
Palm oil is essential - gives food distinctive color and flavor
Ilha de Luanda (the island/peninsula) is the food and nightlife hub
Semba and kizomba music fills restaurants - eating is a social, musical experience
